item.title: Stardew Valley Creepy Audio Glitch Gives the Game a Horror Vibe
item.description:
Highlights

  • Stardew Valley glitch turns cheerful music into unnerving sounds, disturbing fans & sparking comparisons to horror games.
  • Fan shared eerie gameplay clip with audio glitch, sparking suggestions to fix game or uninstall/reinstall.
  • Despite creepy glitch, Stardew Valley is known for its calm and relaxing gameplay experience.

An audio glitch in Stardew Valley turned the charming life sim title into a creepy experience for one fan. The shared clip of the Stardew Valley experience has disturbed other players as well, with some suggesting that it's like something out of a Creepypasta.

Stardew Valley is generally considered to be a relaxing and soothing kind of game. The experiences and relationships one forms with the villagers in town have charmed many, and outside a few creepy moments in Stardew Valley , the majority of the game is far from scary. With music and audio playing a big role in how people perceive media, though, this simple glitch has disturbed a lot of people.

Stardew Valley fan mak0vka shared a gameplay clip of their experience in the game with other fans on Reddit. They say that the glitch initially started while they were in a multiplayer run of Stardew Valley , but after starting a new game, the glitch remained. The clip shows the player waking up on the first day in their new home and is more or less normal as the player starts cutting down brush surrounding the house. However, the audio is unnerving. While the sound effects sound normal, the music has become distorted, slow, and sounds almost off-key, and nothing like how the cheerful spring season background music would normally sound.

Creepy and Calm Clash in Stardew Valley

Fans in the comments have been a bit freaked out about the music getting so messed up. Some suggested solutions for fixing the game, like restarting, verifying the files, or completely uninstalling and reinstalling the game. However, most are simply disturbed by the experience, comparing the game to a horror title or a Creepypasta. Several compared it to creepy music or moments in other games, like suggesting it reminded them of Lavender Town's theme in Pokemon , or renaming the game to "Doki Doki Farm Club," a play on the horror visual novel Doki Doki Literature Club .

Thankfully, this problem is just a basic audio glitch that can likely be fixed with one of the recommendations fans have suggested. However, it's not hard to imagine it being an element of a horror mod for the game. Despite some creepy Stardew Valley headcanons, the game has made its reputation for being sweet and laid-back, but modders have added creepy elements to the game in the past. Starting a horror-themed modded version of the game with this kind of background audio would certainly set the tone from the first moment players start it up.

item.title: 5 Most Well-Hidden Secrets In Horror Games, Ranked
item.description:
Developers love to throw in a little Easter egg or an optional quest into their games as a little inside joke or a way to lessen the general intensity of the plot. The No Country for Old Men rendition in GTA 5 or the newspaper Easter Egg in Uncharted 3 , hinting at the fungus infection in The Last of Us , are some of the most iconic 'hidden content' in gaming history. However, unlike some super popular and big titles in the industry, horror games are a bit more secretive with the secrets they hide in their playthrough.

Horror games are already unsettling and mysterious as is; they keep players on edge constantly with the increasingly disturbing life-and-death situations they put their characters in. Ultimately, players do not get the time or, frankly, the energy to go around looking for hidden plotlines and secrets that do not entirely contribute to the game's progression, considering how they're already too busy running for their lives. However, some of these secrets are simply too good to miss.

Warning: Major Spoilers Ahead!

5 Outlast

The Blair Witch Project Easter Egg

No one can deny the impact Outlast had on the horror game scene when it was first released. It still stands as one of the scariest and the most unhinged horror games ever made, leaving fans with an inexplicable feeling of dread followed by the need to keep going. The game, in essence, was so unsettling, that players barely had time to notice the many secrets that were hidden throughout.

One such secret happens in the basement of Mount Massive Asylum during the sixth chapter of the game. When Miles enters the basement for an objective, he comes across a variant (the aggressive mob in the game) facing the wall. If Miles approaches said variant instead of going his way, the variant ends up instantly killing him. The ominous wall-facing and the aggression from the variant are similar to the ending of the cult classic found-footage movie The Blair Witch Project .

4 Cry of Fear

The Bone-Chilling 911 Call

While not a widely recognized name in the gaming industry in general, Cry of Fear is a well-known title within the horror game community. It's a first-person survival horror game that depends on some pretty predictable tactics to create that familiar feeling of doom most horror games give. Being chased by a monstrous-looking man with a knife, fearing for one's life at every dark corner of the game, or running away from the mad doctor — Cry of Fear effectively uses all these strategies to craft a very unbearable environment.

However, one secret that elevates Cry of Fear from a typical horror game to an almost realistic experience is a chilling 911 call. The main character, Simon Henriksson, has a mobile phone as part of his equipment. Naturally, the first thing players might think to do when they equip the phone is to call 911, all things considered. However, if they do, they won't receive any help from law enforcement. Instead, they'll hear dreadful noises — a mixture of screaming, laughing, and something utterly terrifying — on the other end of the line.

3 Silent Hill 3

The Subtly Horrifying Mirror Room

For all the horror game aficionados, the Silent Hill franchise is not a new name. The entire anthology has received critical acclaim and has a major standing in not only the horror game community but the entire gaming industry. Silent Hill is known for its absolutely wicked storylines, completely wild psychological elements, and a dash of sentimentality. It's also known for the ridiculous amount of Easter Eggs and hidden content it hides in its games, very cleverly.

The third installment of the series, Silent Hill 3 , with Heather Mason as the main character, has a particular interaction with a large mirror in the game, which is easily one of the most skin-crawling moments in not only the game but the entire franchise. Heather enters a room with a large mirror and is mysteriously locked inside. The room and mirror start to distort disturbingly, and eventually, there's a subtle shift in the entire aura of the scene when the mirror stops, well, mirroring Heather. It may not sound that horrifying in-text, but Silent Hill players know how creepy that entire sequence is.

2 Silent Hill 2

The Hilariously Unexpected 'Dog' Ending

Of all Silent Hill games, the second installment stands out as particularly creepy and is widely regarded as one of the best horror games ever made. It also contains a plethora of secrets and hidden content, arguably surpassing the usual amount found in most games — it has a lot of them! However, one of the most iconic secrets in a horror game could arguably be the unlockable 'dog ending' in Silent Hill 2 .

For a game with such a somber ambiance and an almost distressing progression, a 'meme' ending would be the last thing one would expect. However, Silent Hill 2 features a secret unlockable ending involving a certain, very adorable, Shiba Inu. This ending is only accessible after unlocking the other three endings and requires the player to find the 'dog key' near Rosewater Park. Once obtained, they can proceed to the third floor of the Lakeview Hotel to unlock a secret door. Behind the door, they discover a Shiba Inu in front of a large, mysterious machine, revealed to be the mastermind behind the game's events. It's as hilarious as it is absurd.

1 Dead Space

Ingeniously Vague Foreshadowing

Dead Space is another very famous horror franchise that's known for blending sci-fi, exploration, and psychological elements in its games in addition to the typical horror theme. The first installment in the series, of the same name, features one of the best plot twists in gaming history. The interesting part is that despite it being a major turn in the storyline, the entire twist is subtly spoiled throughout the game.

The game has 13 chapters that players have to clear as Isaac Clarke, the protagonist. The first letters of all 13 of these chapters spell 'Nicole is Dead,' insinuating that the main character's love interest, who has been aiding him throughout the game, is merely a hallucination. True to this foreshadowing, the ending reveals that the 'Nicole' Isaac has been hearing and interacting with exists only in his mind, and the real Nicole was never alive.

item.title: Luigi's Mansion 2: All Old Clockworks Gem Locations
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Old Clockworks Gem Locations
  • Rewards for Collecting All Old Clockworks Gems

Once gamers take down the Possessor in Haunted Towers, they'll move onto the third mansion in Luigi's Mansion 2 : Old Clockworks - an abandoned clock tower built over an archeological site. There are several gems in this location but not all of them are easy to spot; they require some digging and investigating.

This guide will show players how they can uncover every gem in this mansion so they're a step closer to completing E. Gadd's vault.

Old Clockworks Gem Locations

Here are the locations of the 13 ruby gems in Old Clockworks:

Gemstone

Room location

How to find

#1

Clockworks Court (F1)

On the right side of the courtyard, use the Strobulb to activate the bomb on the other side of the pile of wood blocking the road. Then, keep going right and use the Dark-Light Device at the end of the rails to uncover a chest with the gem inside.

#2

Warehouse (F1)

Activate the Dark-Light Device on the pile of boxes east of the door that leads to the Roundhouse. This will reveal the hidden green ribbon spool; place it on the unthreading device to get the gem.

#3

Clock Tower Gate (F1)

Go to the western side of the room and flash the Dark-Light Device on the wall by the broken window to reveal a chest with a gem inside.

#4

Storm Cellar (B1)

Remove the sheet covering the painting on top of the bed and then use Dark-Light on it to extract the ruby.

#5

Canyon Stairs (B1)

Vacuum the web on the ceiling in the northeastern corner of the room.

#6

Quarry (B2)

On the ground level, remove the cart from the tunnel and enter it to find the gem.

#7

Clockmaker's Chamber (F2)

Remove the rug to reveal a fan inserted into the floor. Use the Poltergust 5000 to change the time displayed on the clock on the wall. An alarm clock will sound when the digital clock matches the analog clock (9:00), so be sure to set the time correctly to wake up the Greenie. Then, catch it and it will release the gem.

#8

Roundhouse (F2)

After going across the first two beams, come back south through the next pair of beams, located up ahead, and turn the corner to find a chest with a gem.

#9

Roundhouse (F1)

There is a brick wall in the area behind the circular sand pit; enter it from the right side and vacuum the cobweb as well as the gem.

#10

Gear Chamber (B1)

On the eastern wall of the Gear Chamber, there is a path of boxes, and gamers can connect it by using the Dark-Light Device on the gap between them. The bridge will allow the players to reach the door behind the back wall, which will lead them to a secret dimension.

Gamers only have 15 seconds to collect all the red coins. To do it, they must immediately turn left, then use the gear to jump onto the other side and grab the remaining coins.

#11

Maintenance Hub (B1)

Below the massive gear in the middle of the room, there is a hidden chest that can be revealed with the Dark-Light Device.

#12

Service Elevator (F1)

There is a mirror next to the door that leads to the Gear Chamber, and it shows not visible to the player: there is a gem on a platform behind their point of view. Using the Poltergust 5000, throw Toad onto the platform, and he'll grab the ruby.

#13

Movements (F1)

After opening the Clock Tower Gate, go to the western area of the room and look out the window to see the last gem; bring it closer by using the Poltergust 5000.

These gems are unlocked as gamers progress through the missions, so they're ordered accordingly; however, many of them can be found in other missions if players backtrack.

If players catch all the Boos hidden in the Old Clockworks Mansion, they'll unlock a bonus mission called Outlandish Interruption , and here, they'll be able to access most of the gems in the mansion as well. So, if they don't mind taking longer to complete the mission, this will end up saving them time, as they won't have to level-hop to get them all.

Rewards for Collecting All Old Clockworks Gems

Once gamers have gathered all 13 gems in Old Clockworks, they'll be able to view a Luigi statue decorated with rubies whenever they go to Professor E. Gadd's vault in Luigi's Mansion 2 .

item.title: Ranking The 10 Best Isometric RPGs
item.description: Isometric RPGs have been a popular sub-genre for decades, and with the fairly recent success of Baldur’s Gate 3, we ranked our picks for the best in the genre and how well they stack up against each other.

item.title: World Of Warcraft: Cataclysm Classic - All Primary Professions, Ranked
item.description:
Highlights

  • The Cataclysm expansion in WoW didn't add new primary professions, but added new recipes and ingredients for existing ones.
  • Skinning is a situational gathering profession that is popular among Rogue and Hunter characters for obtaining materials.
  • Engineering is considered the most versatile profession in WoW, offering useful trinkets, gear, toys, explosives, and mounts.

One of the ways to customize a character in World of Warcraft is to choose their professions, and every character can have two in their spell books at any given time. The Cataclysm expansion didn't introduce any new primary professions, but it did add an impressive variety of new recipes, ingredients, and creative ways to find them.

The Primary professions of WoW are either about finding and collecting ingredients, which is a gathering profession, or having a production profession to put those resources together to make gear, weapons, a variety of consumables, and even rare and expensive items like mounts, pets, and toys. Which professions are the best is always a matter of opinion, and some of the recent changes in Cataclysm have made the best professions even better.

11 Skinning

Gathering Profession

  • Often a profession of Rogues or Hunters

Hunters are often skinners, and not only for the obvious role-playing tie-ins. Most animals, including dinosaurs and lizards, can be harvested for their leather, scales, or other materials. High-level skinning includes animals like dragonkin, so make sure to loot those epic corpses.

Skinning is the most situational of the primary professions because the materials collected can only be used to make a few certain materials other than gear. The upside of this is that leather goods tend to be expensive and characters can sell their excess materials for a handsome fee.

10 Herbalism

Gathering Profession

  • Tauren characters get the Cultivation buff, +15 to Herbalism at all times

Herbalism isn't just knowledge of certain special plants but where to use them, which is why the Tauren have some extra skill when they take on this profession. The most common production professions combined with Herbalism are Alchemy or Inscription, both of which use herbs as their primary ingredient.

Another possibility for those who are more interested in trade than crafting is to sell herbs on the Auction House. Now that they're used for two professions, these humble plants are worth more.

9 Blacksmithing

Production Profession

  • Popular with Warriors

Blacksmithing is one of those useful, practical, but less than exciting Professions unless the player can wear the items they craft. They are almost always Miners because buying materials is often expensive, and mining is a nice way to make extra gold.

A new feature that was introduced with Jewelcrafting is the Blacksmithing ability to make sockets for certain kinds of gear that allow the player to add an extra gem to their gear,

8 Leatherworking

Production Profession

  • Not only clothing but also riding crops and containers

Leatherworking is a situational production profession, with little to offer outside of the medium armor used by Rogues, Druids, Shamans, and Hunters. Armor kits and riding crops, which are used to improve the durability of some gear and speed up one's ground mount are exceptions and can be used by any character.

Like the outdoorsy classes that tend to be Leatherworkers, this profession doesn't require any special equipment like an anvil or special vials to craft certain items.

7 Mining

Gathering Profession

  • Connected to several Production professions including Blacksmithing, Jewelcrafting, and Engineering

One of the most versatile professions when it comes to both crafting and making extra gold, Mining is both popular and lucrative. It not only yields resources like copper and gold but also gemstones and magical nodes like Volatile Earth.

Now that the secondary profession of Archaeology has been introduced, everyone can experience a similar thrill of digging up treasure.

6 Enchanting

Production Profession

  • A favorite of Mages and Warlocks

Enchanting has always been one of Warcraft 's most important professions, especially in the early days of Classic when high-level enchants would make low-level weapons and gear very powerful. In the game's primary "service" profession, characters that run Heroic dungeons or take part in raiding must have optimized gear, and this requires the skills of an Enchanter.

Enchanters can now record their spells on scrolls and sell them at the Auction House, and these scrolls can be purchased from vendors or made by Inscriptionists.

5 Tailoring

Production Profession

  • Make unique mounts and bags in addition to gear and cosmetic clothing

There are so many best-in-slot items that are made by Tailoring that most Warlocks and Mages have this as one of their Primary Professions. Acquiring the materials for it doesn't require another profession because cloth drops come from killing humanoid enemies as opposed to using another profession.

Virtually all of the fancy cosmetic clothes that players wear for fun, like nightgowns and tuxedos, are made by a Tailor, and it's an even more lucrative profession on an RP server.

4 Inscription

Production Profession

  • Not just for Enchantments anymore

Inscription was introduced with The Wrath of the Lich King expansion, and it pairs nicely with Herbalism or Enchanting. Both Professions use a few of the same ingredients, and the power of Inscription gives a character the ability to craft a special kind of scroll that can store an Enchantment for later use.

Herbs are used to make the ink that is an Inscriptionist's primary tool, so the player could either buy them or take up the Herbalism profession.

3 Alchemy

Production Profession

  • Also includes transmutation with gems and metals along with potions and elixirs

Every Guild has a few high-level Alchemists on hand to make the flasks, elixirs, and potions, which are mandatory for raiding the PvP combat. Some of these concoctions can be extremely expensive and require the cooperation of other professions, such as Miners and Herbalists.

Alchemists can also transmute gems and metals into rare and valuable materials for other professions. It's an in-demand service profession for those who don't mind selling their wares.

2 Jewelcrafting

Production Profession

  • Popular with Miners and very lucrative

Of course, the expansion that gave players the rich and decadent culture of the Blood Elves would also include Jewelcrafting. It's not just about crafting rings and necklaces, which is one way to get an edge on bonuses while leveling, but cutting high-level gems for endgame content.

Mining is the best gathering profession to pair with Jewelcrafting. Rough gems are found by sifting through pre-smelted ore and settings can be made using materials like gold, bronze, and copper.

1 Engineering

Production Profession

  • The most versatile Profession of all, it has benefits for every class

Engineering has consistently been the best Primary Profession in World of Warcraft , even since the earliest days of the game. The list of useful trinkets, gear, toys, and even mounts is a long and compelling one that includes motorcycles, glowing goggles, a variety of explosives, and life-saving items like parachutes and defibrillators.

Most Engineers choose Mining, and combining these two professions is both lucrative and fun. Players can sell any of the resources they use, and some of the things they can craft, like the Mechano-hog, are some of the most valuable items in the game.
